repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
The intro message doesn't work very well with multigrid UI:s The message is plainly drawn on the `default_grid` which is kinda ok in TUI but doesn't provide any useful context for external UI:s.

Introduce a new `msg_intro` event with is used when `ext_multigrid` and/or `ext_messages` is set.

Fixes #24705

comment_data.body:
Instead of a special-purpose event would it make sense to emit as `[msg_show, kind="intro", ...]`? Of course, `kind=intro` needs to be specially handled by UIs, but any legacy UIs that handle `msg_show` will still have reasonable behavior.

I also wondered if we need new msg_show fields like  `width`, `height`, `x_offset`, `y_offset`, but the UI could choose to "center" the text when it sees kind=intro.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -829,5 +831,10 @@ events, which the UI must handle.
 ["msg_history_clear"] ~
 	Clear the |:messages| history.
 
+							*ui-event-msg_intro*
+["msg_intro", lines] ~

comment_data.body:
The problem with that is that it requires `ext_messages`, which also implicitly enables `ext_cmdline`, so then we are forced to handle both of those manually.

In Neovide, we have made the decision to keep our UI as true to the regular Neovim UI as possible, and externalizing those makes that much harder, since the layout no longer matches.

comment_regular_data.body:
I integrated this into Neovide here https://github.com/neovide/neovide/pull/1985

However, there's one problem. When I run `:intro` manually, it first shows the text `press ENTER or type command to continue`, before showing the intro. 

It would be good to get rid of that message. Or perhaps better, to know if `:intro` has been manually run so that a proper popup can be shown, and then automatically closed when the user press a key.

This feature is very attractive for GUIs that support multigrid UI.
Here is my impression of this features.

* I don't know when to hide the message displayed by `msg_intro`. Should I hide it when the next `redraw` event occurs? Or, if it is notified by an event like `msg_intro_hide`, it would be easier to handle.

* As a GUI developer, I feel that it would be better if intro messages are emitted by `grid_line` events as well as normal buffer display, and clearing of intros is controlled by `grid_line` events as well. It would be more reasonable if the control by `msg_intro` is triggered when the externalization option is enabled, for example, `ext_msg_intro`.

I agree, it's pretty hard to do correctly, and needs to be coupled by something like this https://github.com/neovide/neovide/blob/a27de281d4d2eea22228b41712ae58dab6c95898/lua/intro.lua. 

It does the following things:
1. Center the lines
2. Center the actual message when the window is resized.
3. Applies the correct highlights
4. Closes the message on certain autocommands.

But this implementation is still buggy, and in some cases, it fails to close as can be seen here https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/24856 and https://github.com/neovide/neovide/pull/1980

Note the Neovide implementation is more complex than needed, since it also deals with older versions of Neovim.

I think it would be fine, if the lua code was maintained and part of Neovim instead. And that's roughly how I would have done it myself.

> I don't know when to hide the message displayed by msg_intro

The root issue is that this is not defined in vim to start with. it just disappears whenever there is a particular kind of redraw (usefully, when the user changed the buffer. not so usefully, when there was an async event which caused a NOT_VALID redraw).

We could look into improve this, but it would be a separate change which involves and specifies the behavior regardless of the kind of UI.

> I think it would be fine, if the lua code was maintained and part of Neovim instead. And that's roughly how I would have done it myself.

Well, a gui could use a lua function like this to display a float but pass in the test from the `msg_intro` message instead of maintaining a copy of the text

I have now fixed the issue that caused the intro message to get stuck in Neovide, it turns out that `packer.nvim` can cause `VimEnter` to be sent at least twice. @akiyosi, feel free to copy what you need from our implementation here https://github.com/neovide/neovide/pull/1985, especially the lua part for actually showing and closing the message.

@bfredl 
>>I think it would be fine, if the lua code was maintained and part of Neovim instead. And that's roughly how I would have done it myself.

> Well, a gui could use a lua function like this to display a float but pass in the test from the msg_intro message instead of maintaining a copy of the text

That's what I'm doing now, but as I explained before, it's not that trivial to get right, and it's something that each GUI needs to implement separately or copy from each other. That said, it's probably better to externalize it from nvim from now, since there are big chances that our implementation still isn't bug-free. But I think the more long-term solution for nvim should be to provide something that "just works".

But there are a few issues that still needs to be resolved here, I don't think I can do it from my lua script.
1. Provide a way to get rid of `press ENTER or type command to continue` that is shown when you type `:intro` and before `msg_intro` is received.
2. Add a paramter that tells if the message was invoked manually or automatically at startup. In the later case I would prefer if we could display a more popup like window.
3. Provide a translated message that can be used in combination with that. Similar to the `LspInfo` -  `Press q or <Esc> to close this window` 
4. I don't think it should be tied to just `multigrid`. We have the same problem of the message getting automatically closed when re-sizing without multi-grid as well.
